message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the signs of a dead tree. When a tree is dead, it means that it no longer has any living tissue and is no longer capable of performing its natural functions. Option (B) is correct because when a beaver uses a dead tree to stop up a flowing river, it shows that the tree no longer has any structural integrity and is incapable of supporting itself. Options (A), (C), and (D) are incorrect because they describe activities or interactions that can occur with a live or even dying tree.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the signs of a dead tree. Option (B) is correct because when a tree is dead, it no longer has a flow of sap and nutrients to support its growth, making it easier for a beaver to use it to stop up a flowing river. Option (A) is unrelated because the presence of a raccoon does not indicate whether a tree is dead or alive. Option (C) is also unrelated as the presence of a possum does not indicate the tree's health. Option (D) is incorrect because an owl living in a tree does not indicate whether the tree is dead or alive.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the life cycle of trees. A tree is considered dead when it no longer has any living tissue or when it cannot support any growth or new leaves. Option (B) is correct because when a beaver uses a tree to stop up a flowing river, it indicates that the tree is no longer alive and cannot resist the force of the water. Options (A), (C), and (D) are incorrect because they do not necessarily indicate that the tree is dead. A raccoon scurrying up the trunk, a possum hiding in the branches, or an owl living in the tree does not necessarily mean that the tree is dead.

Options (A), (C), and (D) are incorrect because they describe animals interacting with the tree, which does not necessarily determine whether the tree is dead or alive.

The beaver's actions also indicate that the tree is no longer functioning as a living organism. 

Options (A), (C), and (D) are incorrect because they involve animals interacting with the tree, but these interactions do not necessarily indicate that the tree is dead. Raccoons, possums, and owls can still live in a tree even if it is alive, as long as the tree provides suitable habitat for these animals. Therefore, the presence of these animals does not definitively signify the death of a tree.
